title.narrative: Improving Rice Workers’ Conditions, Human Capital and Resilience to Reduce Child Labor Risks in Punjab, Pakistan – Sustainable Scale-up Initiative

description.narrative: Pakistan is one of the world’s top 10 rice exporting countries. Over 700,000 farm laborers are involved in rice cultivation, of which a substantial number are women transplanters. Rice transplanting is a significant source of income for women in some regions of Pakistan. In Pakistan, poverty is a driving factor for the presence of child labour in agriculture overall.Research indicates that in the rice producing regions, young children, especially below 11 years, are not engaged in transplanting operations. However, due to a lack of alternatives, some children sit and play in the fields. Shelters are often lacking, which can expose them to extremely humid and hot weather. There are some hazardous conditions on the farm as well. School attendance of the children is low throughout the year for various reasons and dropout rate is high.As noted above, contributing factors include economic poverty, and the related need to increase family productivity. Women working in rice transplanting indicate that that they may bring children along during work because they feel there is no safe space in their community to leave their children behind. Low human capital (e.g. poor healthcare and lack of access to educational opportunities) further deepening their vulnerabilities also play a role.Mars, RPL, FHRI, and CARE are proposing 'Improving rice workers’ conditions, human capital and resilience to reduce child labour risks in Punjab, Pakistan – Sustainable scale-up initiative” to three rice-growing districts to sustainably address child labour root causes in the rice value chain leveraging proven interventions in the 2017-2019 pilot, combined with new elements to improve program sustainability and its longer-term impact. This aims to directly impact 21,450 transplanters, children, young adults, and community members and raise awareness on human and child rights of at least 25,400 individuals and 150 rice millers in the system.
